subject: keyboard/lexical set proposal
msgSnippet: I am proposing a new way to assign ASCII letters that is a compromise between the SAMPA proposal and my proposal, and which will hopefully make things clearer.
messageBody:
I am proposing a new way to assign ASCII letters that is a compromise
between the SAMPA proposal and my proposal, and which will hopefully
make things clearer.

I don't think we should accept the SAMPA encoding as the default, since
it forces users to forgo some natural pairs. Specifically, for years all
of us
have have typed "y" for the sound in Yes [j], "j" for the sound in
"judge" [dZ], and "I" for the proper pronoun [aI]. I can't accept giving
up such an obvious keyboard mapping simply because SAMPA, a tool for
linguists, and seemingly based on European languages in general rather
than English specifically, says so. So I think we should adopt a
standard for ASCII based on what is easiest for English speakers to use
and remember. SAMPA is no more a standard for QS than the meter is for
measuring the volume of water.

It has occurred while editing a dictionary for QS that I needed to
encode my words in lexical sets rather than the representations for QS
letters. For example, the dictionary I am using has _bore_ represented
as [kU@r]. It took me a while to realize that the [U@r] belonged to the
lexical set CURE. I had edited over 3,000 words when I became certain of
this, and many of those words I used the letters Wool + Ado + Roar.
Probably the Ado does not belong, so I have to go back and change a lot
of words.

It would have been simpler for me to encode the word boor as such:

boor b-CURE

where the words on the left is the TO word, and the word on the right is
the transliteration. Now when it comes time to finalize the dictionary,
I can simply replace all instances of -CURE with whatever QS letters we
decided were appropriate.

There are a lot of such instances where I am making decisions on what
letters to use, thereby losing information that I may want later, and
which I cannot retrieve except by going back and re-editing 80,000
words. For example, I have been removing the unstressed vowels before
_r_ in words like _better_. It would be better if I had entered the word as:

better b-DRESS-t-LETTER

Later I can decide if I want to change LETTER to /ar/ or just to /r/.
The same is true of the _y_ endings at the end of words, such as Betty.

betty b-DRESS-t-HAPPY

We can decide later if we want HAPPY to become /i/ or /I/.

My proposal states that we assign a letter to each lexical set, rather
than each QS letter. In practice, we mostly do this, but we completely
ignore some important lexical sets and merge others. We should keep the
same letters that John originally suggested, the ones based on SAMPA.
Thus, /i/ still becomes Eat, part of the FLEECE lexical set. In an
email, the convention of using John's SAMPA mapping still would more or
less hold, with the exception that we think of the letters as
representing lexical sets rather than actual letters.

In practice, _dress_ becomes /drEs/, the same as it was. We can still
paste that into a word processor, choose ThothSampa, and get a good QS
representation.

But the word _bird_ would become /bDd/, where D represents the NURSE
lexical set. We should no longer think in terms of ligatures, which are
just a typographical convention, but in terms of lexical sets, so that
the /D/ in this case should be as much as the standard as /E/.

This means that the font ThothSampa would have to be changed slightly.
First, I would like to change the name to ThothLexical, a small change.
More importantly, I would need to make sure there is a sensible
representation for some of the lexical sets not yet represented, such as
Happy /K/. That means just letting the key "K" represent Eat.

Here is the full mapping proposal, with lexical sets, or pseudal lexical
sets, on the left and the letter to represent them on the right. The
comments come after the "#".

Paul

PS One other advantage of using lexical sets in this way is that it can
handle some of the mergers better. If I have all the BATH words
separated from the PATH words (admitedly not an easy task), I can choose
one vowel for a British transliteration and one for an American
transliteration. I think?!

Bob b
Kick k
Church c
Deed d
Fife f
Gig g # Alternate names Game
Haha h # Alternate names Hot, hat
Judge J
Vision Z
Loll l # Alternate names Lid
Mime m
Nun n
Inkling N # Alternate names Sung
Pipe p
Roar r
Sis s # alternate names Suace
Shush S # alternate names Ship
Tut t
Thin T
The D # alternate names This, Thither
Valve v
Win w
What W
Yoyo j # alternate names Yes
Zoos z
Face e
Trap a
Palm A
Thought O
Fleece i
Dress E
Price Y
Kit I
Goat o
Lot Q
Cloth M # No dialect has Thought, Cloth, and Lot, so we can dispense
with Cloth

Mouth H
Choice R
Strut V
Goose u
Foot U
Square X
Near C
Start B
North P
Force F
Comma a
Letter G
Happy K
Nurse D
Cure L
